title: Impaired
data:
- *For player impairment, see [Stun](/wiki/Stun "Stun") and [Confusion](/wiki/Confusion "Confusion").*

Typically a [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster")'s movement follows a predictable pattern. When the monster is affected by certain [properties](/index.php?title=Monster_property\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Monster property (page does not exist)"), or it believes the [player](/wiki/Player "Player") is in a different [square](/wiki/Square "Square") to his actual location, these patterns can be disrupted. Such a monster is said to be [impaired](). This is a useful shorthand when describing a monster's usual behaviour, by adding the caveat *"unless the [foo](/wiki/Foo "Foo") is impaired"*.

[Conflict](/wiki/Conflict "Conflict") is not considered an impairment, but a separate category of its own.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Impairing monster properties](#Impairing_monster_properties)

  - [1.1 Confused](#Confused)
  - [1.2 Stunned](#Stunned)
  - [1.3 Scared](#Scared)
  - [1.4 Blind](#Blind)

- [2 Player properties that impair monsters](#Player_properties_that_impair_monsters)

  - [2.1 Invisibility](#Invisibility)
  - [2.2 Displacement](#Displacement)

## Impairing monster properties

The following monster properties can cause atypical monster behaviour.

### Confused

- *Main article: [Confusion](/wiki/Confusion "Confusion")*

A [confused](/wiki/Confused "Confused") monster will move randomly, and may blunder into and attack a player it might not otherwise, unless he is protected by [Elbereth](/wiki/Elbereth "Elbereth"), a [scroll of scare monster](/wiki/Scroll_of_scare_monster "Scroll of scare monster") or [sanctuary](/wiki/Sanctuary "Sanctuary").

### Stunned

- *Main article: [Stun](/wiki/Stun "Stun")*

The NetHack movement subroutines include code to modify monster behaviour when [stunned](/wiki/Stun "Stun"). It is not clear what effect (if any) this produces in the result of these routines.

### Scared

- *Main article: [Scare](/wiki/Scare "Scare")*

Generally, monsters that are [scared](/wiki/Scare "Scare") run away from you. This may cause them to use a [ranged attack](/wiki/Ranged_attack "Ranged attack") they would not otherwise have used.

### Blind

- *Main article: [Blindness](/wiki/Blindness "Blindness")*

Monsters with eyes that are [blind](/wiki/Blind "Blind") (e.g. from a [camera](/wiki/Expensive_camera "Expensive camera")) will move randomly, in a fashion similar to confused monsters, save that they will not respect Elbereth.

## Player properties that impair monsters

If you are [invisible](/wiki/Invisible "Invisible") or [displaced](/wiki/Displacement "Displacement"), monsters that do not yet know your true position will assume you are on a square near to your current location, and behave accordingly.

### Invisibility

- *Main article: [Invisibility](/wiki/Invisibility "Invisibility")*

Monsters will be unable to locate [invisible](/wiki/Invisible "Invisible") players, unless they can [see invisible](/wiki/See_invisible "See invisible") or have hit the player since the player last moved. They will assume the player is on a square within 1 square of his current location and move accordingly. Generally they will end up next to the player's assumed location, so use of ranged attacks on adjacent invisible players is not common.

### Displacement

- *Main article: [Displacement](/wiki/Displacement "Displacement")*

Monsters will be unable to locate players whose image is [displaced](/wiki/Displacement "Displacement"), unless they have hit the player since he last moved. They will assume the player is on a square within 2 squares of his current location and move accordingly. This makes it less likely that monsters will score a melee hit, but makes the use of ranged attacks possible.

[![This article may require revision for the next version of NetHack. Click here for more information.](/images/b/b0/Nh343-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article may require revision for the next version of NetHack. Click here for more information.")

**This page may need to be updated for the [current version](/wiki/Current_version "Current version") of *NetHack*.**

It may contain text specific to [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3"). Information on this page may be out of date.

**Editors:** After reviewing this page and making necessary edits, please change the {{nethack-343}} tag to the current version's tag or {{noversion}} as appropriate.
html:
Impaired

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
For player impairment, see Stun and Confusion.

Typically a monster's movement follows a predictable pattern. When the monster is affected by certain properties, or it believes the player is in a different square to his actual location, these patterns can be disrupted. Such a monster is said to be impaired. This is a useful shorthand when describing a monster's usual behaviour, by adding the caveat "unless the foo is impaired".

Conflict is not considered an impairment, but a separate category of its own.

Contents

  • 1 Impairing monster properties
    • 1.1 Confused
    • 1.2 Stunned
    • 1.3 Scared
    • 1.4 Blind
  • 2 Player properties that impair monsters
    • 2.1 Invisibility
    • 2.2 Displacement

Impairing monster properties

The following monster properties can cause atypical monster behaviour.

Confused

Main article: Confusion

A confused monster will move randomly, and may blunder into and attack a player it might not otherwise, unless he is protected by Elbereth, a scroll of scare monster or sanctuary.

Stunned

Main article: Stun

The NetHack movement subroutines include code to modify monster behaviour when stunned. It is not clear what effect (if any) this produces in the result of these routines.

Scared

Main article: Scare

Generally, monsters that are scared run away from you. This may cause them to use a ranged attack they would not otherwise have used.

Blind

Main article: Blindness

Monsters with eyes that are blind (e.g. from a camera) will move randomly, in a fashion similar to confused monsters, save that they will not respect Elbereth.

Player properties that impair monsters

If you are invisible or displaced, monsters that do not yet know your true position will assume you are on a square near to your current location, and behave accordingly.

Invisibility

Main article: Invisibility

Monsters will be unable to locate invisible players, unless they can see invisible or have hit the player since the player last moved. They will assume the player is on a square within 1 square of his current location and move accordingly. Generally they will end up next to the player's assumed location, so use of ranged attacks on adjacent invisible players is not common.

Displacement

Main article: Displacement

Monsters will be unable to locate players whose image is displaced, unless they have hit the player since he last moved. They will assume the player is on a square within 2 squares of his current location and move accordingly. This makes it less likely that monsters will score a melee hit, but makes the use of ranged attacks possible.

This page may need to be updated for the current version of NetHack.

It may contain text specific to NetHack 3.4.3. Information on this page may be out of date.

Editors: After reviewing this page and making necessary edits, please change the {{nethack-343}} tag to the current version's tag or {{noversion}} as appropriate.

Retrieved from "https://nethackwiki.com/index.php?title=Impaired&oldid=140731"

rawPage:
{{For|player impairment|Stun|Confusion}}
Typically a [[monster]]'s movement follows a predictable pattern. When the monster is affected by certain [[monster property|properties]], or it believes the [[player]] is in a different [[square]] to his actual location, these patterns can be disrupted. Such a monster is said to be [[impaired]]. This is a useful shorthand when describing a monster's usual behaviour, by adding the caveat ''"unless the [[foo]] is impaired"''.

[[Conflict]] is not considered an impairment, but a separate category of its own.

==Impairing monster properties==

The following monster properties can cause atypical monster behaviour.

===Confused===
{{main|Confusion}}

A [[confused]] monster will move randomly, and may blunder into and attack a player it might not otherwise, unless he is protected by [[Elbereth]], a [[scroll of scare monster]] or [[sanctuary]].

===Stunned===
{{main|Stun}}
The NetHack movement subroutines include code to modify monster behaviour when [[stun]]ned. It is not clear what effect (if any) this produces in the result of these routines.

===Scared===
{{main|Scare}}
Generally, monsters that are [[scare]]d run away from you. This may cause them to use a [[ranged attack]] they would not otherwise have used.

===Blind===
{{main|Blindness}}
Monsters with eyes that are [[blind]] (e.g. from a [[Expensive camera|camera]]) will move randomly, in a fashion similar to confused monsters, save that they will not respect Elbereth.

==Player properties that impair monsters==

If you are [[invisible]] or [[displacement|displaced]], monsters that do not yet know your true position will assume you are on a square near to your current location, and behave accordingly.

===Invisibility===
{{main|Invisibility}}
Monsters will be unable to locate [[invisible]] players, unless they can [[see invisible]] or have hit the player since the player last moved. They will assume the player is on a square within 1 square of his current location and move accordingly. Generally they will end up next to the player's assumed location, so use of ranged attacks on adjacent invisible players is not common.

===Displacement===
{{main|Displacement}}
Monsters will be unable to locate players whose image is [[displacement|displaced]], unless they have hit the player since he last moved.
They will assume the player is on a square within 2 squares of his current location and move accordingly. This makes it less likely that monsters will score a melee hit, but makes the use of ranged attacks possible.

[[Category:Monster attributes]]
{{nethack-343}}
